   This is a 65 year old male with a history of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and
   diabetes who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with RVR and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis.
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: Believe this has been chronic, given
   dilated LV and decreased EF on echo; believed due to dilation from
   novel cardiomyopathy. He has not responded to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion.  HR first improved with digoxin, amiodarone and
   occasional use of esmolol gtt and pressors.  Refractory afib with
   difficult to control rates may be [**2-19**] pericardial irritation vs.
   inflammatory drive from malignancy; see below for onc management plan,
   also concern for metastatic cancer to myocardium.  Now back in atrial
   fibrillation despite previous sinus following cardioversion, AV node
   modification and pacer placement, and continuation of po Amiodarone.
   - continue Amiodarone gtt @1mg/min; as per EP
   - consider repeat cardioversion if patient is in atrial flutter, DNR if
   for instability
   - digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose, per EP
   - heparin gtt stopped [**2-19**] CT head findings (CHADS score 2; hypertension
   and DM)
   - IV Metoprolol as needed to rate control in 120
   .
   # intracranial bleeds
 Patient was found to have asymmetric pupils on
   exam and received CT head c contrast [**11-12**].  This showed no lesion
   worrisome for mass effect, but two new lesions (R frontal, R
   cerebellar) were noted worrisome for metastasis vs. intraparenchymal
   hemorrhage in comparison to prior CT head one week ago.  NSGY was
   consulted and agreed with plan to d/c heparin gtt. (attending addendum
   to CT read) There is now a definite blood/fluid level, layering within
   a 14mm (AP) likely extra-axial collection, in the region of the right
   frontal operculum (2:18), suggesting evolving hemorrhage. Its relation
   to the more anteriorly-located well-defined hyperdense focus is
   unclear. The additional focus, along the right lateral aspect of the
   tentorium cerebelli, level of the ambient cistern, was not clearly
   present and also may represent evolving hemorrhage.
   -          heparin gtt d/ced
   -          MRI head c/w single punctuate hemorrhage, unclear as to
   relationship to mets which are not intraparenchymal
   -          Consider repeat CT scan in several days to reassess
   bleeding, or earlier if clinical situation warrants.
   .
   # Cardiomyopathy: New-found EF of 20% with globally dilated RV.  Most
   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but
   CVP WNL.  Appears to have significant diuretic resistance.
   - monitor I
s & O
s and cardiac index, titrate diuresis to CVP
   - ACE/BB once BP stabilizes and ARF improves
   - Given inability to maintain BP, will hold off on diuresis today.
   - continue statin
   - replace swan today pending family discussion of CMO
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Likely [**2-19**] Afib with RVR and/or infection/sepsis,
   currently only on norepinephrine and vasopressin.  Cardiac index
   unattained when swan was removed, last CVP was elevated as well as
   pulmonary artery pressure .  Worrisome for mixed cardiogenic /
   distributive shock picture.
   - Continue to monitor cardiac index serially once swan replaced
   - Patient self diuresing currently, will hold off on diuretics until
   ARF resolves/improves
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt
   - Norepinephrine
   - continue Vasopressin as needed
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated on [**2148-11-4**] for increased work of
   breathing. Ventilatory support settings stable for days
   - titrate vent settings to ABGs, wean to PSV as tolerated
   - Appreciate ID recs; switched from CTX
 vanc + CTZ + ciprofloxacin
   empirically for now.
   - await H1N1 results from government lab
   .
   # Fevers: (104.5 overnight) likely from influenza vs Merkell.  Switched
   famotidine to PPI out of concern for drug fever.
   -Continue Oseltamivir, Ramantadine for influenza A
   - f/u blood and urine cultures as well as influenza H1N1 send out
   - repeat BCx, UCx, culture from line, consider broadening abx if
   continue to be febrile.
   - would hold off on further cultures for lower grade fevers as all have
   been negative
   - on CTZ, vanc, cipro per ID recs
   - CXR from [**2148-11-12**] showing worsened R lung infiltrates, improved L
   lung aeration
   .
   # [**Location (un) 10939**] Cell Carcinoma: Elevated LDH and finding of R axillary
   lymphadenopathy, CT torso showed c/w malignancy, biopsy consistent with
   Merckel Cell Carcinoma, MRI showing cranial and dural mets.  Poor
   prognosis at this time.
   - f/u Onc, expert recs
   - f/u Derm recs, as there is an attending familiar with [**Location (un) 10939**] Cell
   Carcinoma (await email response.)
   - DNR/DNI, family meeting re: CMO pending
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: Crit stable, s/p transfusion.  Labs not
   concerning for DIC at this time.
   - Daily crit, transfuse for <25.
   - holding off until results of family meeting
   - HIT antibodies negative
   - guaiac stools
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trending down from peak 2.8, 2.4 today up
   from 2.0, baseline 1.1.  Likely [**2-19**] hypoperfusion given hypotension
   ?contribution of diuresis.  UOP adequate.  No indications for dialysis
   at this time.
   - Monitor [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - follow UOP
   - diuresis as discussed above
   .
   # DMII: Last A1c in [**2-26**] was 7.4%. Will hold outpatient medications
   during this admission.   Sugars poorly controlled while in
patient,
   insulin drip intiated [**11-6**].
   - Continue Insulin drip
   .
   # Neurologic changes:  Concern for metastasis of malignancy affecting
   CNS vs. thormboembolic event given a fib, particularly given recent
   L-sided extremity weakness and confusion.   CT head negative for acute
   event, but significant for mass suggestive of metastatic malignancy.
   No intracerebral mets on MRI, cranial and dural involvement noted.
   Mental status not improved today.  Unclear prognosis at this time given
   sedation requirements.
   .
   # Asymmetric LE edema: now appears more symmetric.  Likely secondary to
   HF.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Cholesterol not well controlled according to last
   lipid panel measured in [**11-24**]. Chol: 295, LDL: 192, HDL: 79, TG: 120.
   Changed simvastatin 80mg PO daily to atorvastatin 40mg daily due to
   amiodarone presence and its potentiation of hepatotoxicity.
   - Follow LFT
   .
   # Arthritis: Stable though impossible to assess given mental status
   .
   # Gout: Stable.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes who was admitted with approximately one week of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea. He was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and markedly decreased ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle. He has been diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma, and imaging studies have shown cranial and dural metastases. The patient's condition has deteriorated rapidly, and he is currently in cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. He is also experiencing fevers, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to his underlying cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, and hypotension. This condition can lead to further deterioration in cardiac function and increased risk of death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation. This condition can lead to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, and increased risk of death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to his underlying cardiogenic shock, hypotension, and hypoperfusion. This condition can lead to further kidney damage and increased risk of death.
4. Fevers: The patient's fevers are likely due to his underlying infection, and may be caused by a variety of pathogens, including influenza, Merkel cell carcinoma, and other bacterial or fungal infections. This condition can lead to further complications, such as sepsis, and increased risk of death.
5. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia are likely due to his underlying bone marrow suppression and bleeding diathesis. This condition can lead to further bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, and increased risk of death.
6. Neurologic changes: The patient's neurologic changes are likely due to his underlying cerebral metastases and bleeding diathesis. This condition can lead to further neurologic deterioration, such as increased intracranial pressure, and increased risk of death.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and he requires immediate and aggressive treatment to address his cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, fevers, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neurologic changes.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male with a complex medical condition. Here is a summary of the patient's condition:

* The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.
* He presented with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea, and was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and markedly decreased ejection fraction (EF) with dilated left ventricle.
* He has been diagnosed with [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma, which has metastasized to multiple sites, including the brain, and is likely to be the cause of his cardiac and respiratory dysfunction.
* The patient has developed acute kidney injury (AKI) and is at risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* He has a fever of 104.7°F (40.4°C) and is being treated for possible sepsis.
* The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
* He has a Swan-Ganz catheter in place, which is monitoring his central venous pressure (CVP).
* The patient has been diagnosed with cardiomyopathy, which is likely secondary to tachycardia-induced heart failure.
* He has been prescribed multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia suggest that he may be at risk of developing sepsis.
* ARDS: The patient's respiratory failure and hypoxia make him at risk of developing ARDS.
* Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac dysfunction and pericardial effusion make him at risk of developing cardiac tamponade.
* Hemorrhagic stroke: The patient's recent head CT scan showed new lesions that may be indicative of hemorrhagic stroke.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient's recent DVT prophylaxis and his risk factors for DVT make him at risk of developing pulmonary embolism.
* Renal failure: The patient's AKI and his risk factors for chronic kidney disease make him at risk of developing renal failure.
* Infectious complications: The patient's immunocompromised state and his recent hospitalization make him at risk of developing infectious complications, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following interventions may be necessary:

* Continued monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to detect any changes in his condition.
* Adjustment of his medications and therapies to optimize his treatment.
* Consideration of invasive procedures, such as central venous catheter placement or Swan-Ganz catheter insertion, to monitor his central venous pressure and cardiac function.
* Consideration of non-invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) to support his respiratory function.
* Consideration of dialysis or other renal replacement therapies to support his renal function.
* Consideration of antibiotics or antivirals to treat potential infections.
* Consideration of palliative care and symptom management to improve the patient's quality of life.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-inch tall, 141 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a fever of 104.7°F (40.4°C) and is currently receiving various medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 149 bpm, blood pressure of 100/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 600 mL, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and troponin levels, indicating possible sepsis and cardiac injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and troponin levels suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
2. Cardiac Injury: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and death.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's mechanical ventilation requirements suggest possible respiratory failure, which can lead to further respiratory compromise and death.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels suggest possible renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and death.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible sepsis can lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, cerebral edema, and death.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's possible stress ulcer and possible sepsis can lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, and death.
7. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's prolonged immobility and possible sepsis can increase the risk of VTE, which can lead to pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and death.
8. Infection: The patient's possible sepsis can lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin infections, which can worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of death.

   Assessment and Plan
   65 year old male with a history of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes
   who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with RVR and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis and Influenza A.
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Mixed cardiogenic and distributive picture.
   Likely [**2-19**] Afib with RVR, cardiomyopathy, metastatic carcinoma and/or
   infection/sepsis from influenza A, currently only on norepinephrine and
   dopamine, did not tolerate vasopressin.  Swan has been removed.
   - Continue pressor support
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt and digoxin
   - continue to treat infectious process with antibiotics as below
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Unresponsive to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion, likely secondary to increased sympathetic tone from both
   [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma and influenza A.  The patient likely has a
   dilated cardiomyopathy that is either secondary to or worsened by the
   tachycardia.  The patient is intermittently in sinus rhythm continued
   on amiodarone gtt @1mg/min following large IV load.  The patient is s/p
   AVJ modification with some improvement in amount of time in sinus.
   - continue amiodoarone and digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose,
   per EP
   - heparin gtt stopped [**2-19**] CT head findings (CHADS score 2; hypertension
   and DM)
   - IV Metoprolol as needed to rate control in 120
   .
   # Intracranial bleeds
 Patient was found to have asymmetric pupils on
   exam and received CT head c contrast [**11-12**].  This showed no lesion
   worrisome for mass effect, but two new lesions (R frontal, R
   cerebellar) were noted worrisome for metastasis vs. intraparenchymal
   hemorrhage in comparison to prior CT head one week ago.  NSGY was
   consulted and agreed with plan to d/c heparin gtt. (attending addendum
   to CT read) There is now a definite blood/fluid level, layering within
   a 14mm (AP) likely extra-axial collection, in the region of the right
   frontal operculum (2:18), suggesting evolving hemorrhage. Its relation
   to the more anteriorly-located well-defined hyperdense focus is
   unclear. The additional focus, along the right lateral aspect of the
   tentorium cerebelli, level of the ambient cistern, was not clearly
   present and also may represent evolving hemorrhage.
   -          heparin gtt d/ced
   -          MRI head c/w single punctuate hemorrhage, unclear as to
   relationship to mets which are not intraparenchymal
   -          Consider repeat CT scan in several days to reassess
   bleeding, or earlier if clinical situation warrants.
   .
   # Cardiomyopathy: New-found EF of 20% with globally dilated RV.  Most
   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but
   CVP WNL.  Appears to have significant diuretic resistance.
   - monitor I
s & O
s, titrate diuresis to CVP

   - continue statin
   - replace swan today pending family discussion of CMO

 vanc + CTZ + ciprofloxacin

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes who presents with approximately one week of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea. He was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, cardiomyopathy, and metastatic carcinoma diagnosis. The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications, including hypotension, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, and diabetes. The patient's condition is deteriorating, and the team is considering a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order and discussing comfort measures only (CMO).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest sepsis, which could be caused by the patient's underlying infections, such as pneumonia or influenza A.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation, cardiomyopathy, and hypotension increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to increased hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute renal failure could progress, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential need for dialysis.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia could worsen, increasing the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient's underlying infections, such as pneumonia or influenza A, could worsen, leading to sepsis or organ failure.
7. Metastatic Spread: The patient's metastatic carcinoma could spread to other organs, leading to further complications and poor prognosis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical complications closely.
2. Consider a DNR order and discuss comfort measures only (CMO) with the family.
3. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation, cardiomyopathy, and respiratory failure with medications and mechanical ventilation.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin drip as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. Consider broadening antibiotic coverage if the patient's fever persists or worsens.
7. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider sedation or analgesia as needed.
8. Consider repeating CT scan in several days to reassess bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old man admitted to the ICU with new onset rapid atrial fibrillation, severe cardiomyopathy, and severe sepsis. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer, and has multiple metastases in his brain and lymph nodes. He is currently on pressor support, antibiotics, and antiviral medication for influenza A.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 104.6°F (40.3°C)
* Heart rate: 131 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 110/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 59 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 35 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* LDH: 4210 IU/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: Shows bilateral infiltrates consistent with pneumonia
* Computed tomography (CT) head: Shows multiple metastases in the brain
* Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) head: Shows a single punctuate hemorrhage in the brain

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiomyopathy and tachycardia may lead to cardiogenic shock, which can be life-threatening.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and ARDS may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state may lead to infections, which can be life-threatening.
5. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia may lead to bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient's hypotension and sepsis may lead to acute renal failure, which can be life-threatening.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's diabetes and stress response may lead to hyperglycemia, which can be life-threatening.
8. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may lead to pancreatitis, which can be life-threatening.

Recommendations:

1. Continue pressor support to maintain blood pressure.
2. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis.
3. Continue antiviral medication for influenza A.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's respiratory function and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's lipid levels and adjust therapy as needed.
9. Consider repeat imaging studies to monitor the patient's disease progression.
10. Consider palliative care consultation to discuss end-of-life care options.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia, admitted with new onset rapid atrial fibrillation and severe cardiomyopathy.
* He has been treated with amiodarone, digoxin, and norepinephrine for his arrhythmia and cardiomyopathy, but continues to experience hypotension and shock.
* The patient has a diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma, confirmed by pathology, and is currently too unstable to receive chemotherapy for palliative treatment.
* He has been intubated for respiratory failure and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
* The patient has a fever of 104.6°F, likely due to influenza A, and is receiving empiric antibiotics for possible pneumonia and ARDS.
* He has developed acute kidney injury, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, and is receiving transfusions and dialysis as needed.
* The patient's mental status is altered, and he is not responding to family members or medical staff.
* He has a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia and is receiving treatment with atorvastatin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiomyopathy and arrhythmia may worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure may progress, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
* Infection complications: The patient's fever and respiratory failure may be indicative of a severe infection, which may spread to other parts of the body.
* Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Hematological complications: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding and increased risk of infection.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to further neurological compromise and potential brain damage.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his overall outcome.
